contextId.occurrenceNote: These were ritual mourning actions, symbolizing deep grief. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.glQuote: tore his robe, shaved his head

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was a sign of mourning. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

contextId.glQuote: threw dust into the air and upon his own head

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "bow beneath him" symbolizes submission or defeat. Alternate translation: "he crushes the helpers of Rahab" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.glQuote: the helpers of Rahab bow beneath him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a symbolic action representing asking God for help. Alternate translation: "had made an appeal and prayed to God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.glQuote: had reached out with your hands toward God

contextId.occurrenceNote: "he has shook his fist against God." This is a sign of aggression. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.glQuote: he has reached out with his hand against God

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an action that shows disapproval. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

"people spit in my face." In this culture spitting on someone was a great insult. If spitting has a different meaning in your culture you can write this differently. Alternate translation: "people insult me greatly, by spitting in my face" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

"cover your mouth with your hand." Possible meanings are that 1) this is a response to being astonished. Alternate translation: "cover your mouth with your hand" or 2) this is a symbol that the person will not speak. Alternate translation: "do not say anything" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.glQuote: lay your hand upon your mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Clapping the hands is a way of mocking someone. Here it represents the wind making loud noises. Alternate translation: "It makes loud noises like someone clapping his hands to mock him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: It claps its hands at him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The wind makes a noise as it blows him out of his place, and the noise is like the hissing sound that people make to mock someone. Alternate translation: "it makes a hissing noise as it causes him to leave his home" or "it blows him out of his place and makes a hissing noise like someone who hisses at him to mock him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
This is a symbol of respect. It can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: "rose and stood respectfully for me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
This was a sign of respect. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.glQuote: The princes used to refrain from talking when I came

contextId.occurrenceNote: They did this to show that they would not speak. This was a sign of their respect for Job. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.glQuote: they would lay their hand on their mouths

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "my mouth" represents Job. This is a sign of love and devotion. Alternate translation: "so that I have kissed my hand" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.glQuote: so that my mouth has kissed my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sitting in dust and ashes is a symbolic act showing the person is sorry. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.glQuote: I repent in dust and ashes
